>The Slat Abn Shaif Synagogue is completed in Libya
>Cormeilles Abbey is completed in Normandy

Anonymous Sat 22 Aug 2020 02:58:52 No.32287893 Report
Quoted By: >>32298393
>Early Human-Anthro relations
>From Wankipedia, the encyclopedia that begs for money like a yeen sitting on the sidewalk every six months
>It is believed early nomadic anthro and human tribes began coexistence when one or both tribes suffered losses sufficient that the population alone could no longer sustain itself
>Tribes that joined together enjoyed greater variety in ability, allowing for cooperation based on evolutionary specialization
>it is believed this success is why human/anthro coexistence is accepted to this day
>the most predominant and well-documented example is in hunting pairs
>An anthro and a human have different methods of visual processing- for example, humans have very good motion based vision, while anthros better pick out shapes and colors while hunting prey
>this combination of ability improved the success of early hunters
>depending on the animal hunted, either an anthro or Human would make a first strike, to be followed up by the other hunter
>in the case of animals with 'flight' instinct, such as wild deer, the human typically strikes first by throwing a spear which- if the animal was not killed outright- would be followed by the anthro tracking and finishing off the wounded prey
>for animals with 'fight' instinct, such as boar, the anthro often attacked the animal in an ambush, either killing or pinning it for the human partner to finish off at a safer distance or angle
>It is believed this system may have affected social dynamics outside of the hunt, with different cultures placing greater or lesser value on either the first or killing strike
>this combined effort reduced the risk and energy expenditure of hunting, as well as allowing primitive peoples to take down larger, healthier game hunters of one species might struggle to kill instead of picking off sick or elderly stragglers

There's also the question of which way the commentary leans. It's obvious nowadays because the political commentary overwhelms any sense of identity the show or script could provide in the name of being retarded, but back when, that sort of thing tended to be more allegorical or flatly humanitarian. Old trek comes to mind since while it was progressive for its time it never went full tilt lefty-pol and plenty of episodes presented things in a roughly bi-partisan, and most importantly, respectful manner. Old trek didn't have cardboard stand-ins for the president and didn't debase itself with name calling either side. Nu-trek shits itself in the middle of the playground and screams that it's the rich kid's fault. Nobody is allowed to make a statement right of Stalin or just go about their business anymore.

Anonymous Sat 22 Aug 2020 08:46:08 No.32293854 Report
Quoted By: >>32305837
>>32288897
>>32289292
The whole point with scifi, outside of the speculative science of course, is in the moral and ethics of the unknown. Journeying through the universe to find new and strange situations, cultures and phenomenons that would shine new light on ancient questions or press humans to their limits in how they would choose to proceed. It's not
>oh shit, <thing>! we have to come up with a way to defeat <thing> now - what if we <techno babble> into large explosions? also women can do math, too!
it's
>wait, your culture allows children to murder their parents because growing old means you become a burden to society unless you keep yourself fit enough to survive random assassination attempts, and this was all brought about by the very inhospitable environment in which you live where death is a constant companion and resources are scarce - meaning anyone who doesn't pull their weight is a liability? can we really accept that?

Anonymous Sat 22 Aug 2020 12:50:05 No.32295955 Report
Quoted By: >>32296067 >>32298901
>>32295850
And it's not necessarily something the writer has to communicate immediately or straight up front.
Taking the example of older Trek, the Klingons and Ferengi (thanks to DS9) provided counterexamples to the Federation. The whole of that conflict already existed in the best stories - the "I'm right, from a certain point of view" - and let the intelligent viewer fill in the blanks.

It's why I feel we got the progression from the 70s dystopia as it moved towards the 90s antihero. A world without black and white labels is far more realistic, but easier to pull of badly.
And you're right that we've rebounded back to a flatter view.

It's why I like writing with three sides
Anonymous
  • Post

Anonymous Sat 22 Aug 2020 13:01:39 No.32296067 Report
Quoted By: >>32296264 >>32302651
>>32295955
>easier to pull of badly
I think you hit the nail on the head there. It's easier to write a story about why your point of view, that you're intimately familiar with, is right, than to write a story that showcases both sides and lets the reader see the pros and cons by themselves. The latter means you have to step out of your bubble and do research, risking to learn something new or offend someone when you don't get in line. Someone might call you a racist because you write a racist character, or call you an SJW because you don't immediately pain a progressive idea as bad. The former allows you to lean back into your comfort zone and write what you know your peers want to read, and you can easily wave away any criticism because you take a perceived moral high ground where everyone who disagrees with you is automatically immoral. Just look at modern journalism and tell me it's not all degrading towards path of least resistance
Anonymous

>Strength and speed is a huge factor for wild animals when fighting, but both can be negated by a combination of good motion based vision, prediction, mechanical advantage and technique
>Indo-europeans and mongoloids in particular seem to be best at this
>Anthro tribes become incorporated into human ones due to the strong martial traditions and capability of human hunters

This is kind of related to the above criticism as well. I was still sort of rushed, even with the days off and getting used to the new sleep schedule. I didn't do as much proof reading and tweaking as I normally do. The two sections you guys pointed out could do with some extra exposition.

I think the problem I'm having is that the story shifted focus from just Jake to Jake and Charlotte. So I'm effectively shorting the sections by virtue of having to cover both perspectives. I need to default to adding more. This happened with the last update too and I wound up expanding a section to have Jake and Charlotte interacting more. I might do that again, before the next proper update.

Also I think "mapping out the plot" has kind of hindered me here. I wrote the bulk of the story making it up as I went with only a vague idea of plot trajectory. Since I mapped it out thoroughly I think I'm focusing too much on getting to the next plot point instead of feeling out what should get the characters from place to place. I'll try and keep these things in mind, going forward.

I've read at least one science fiction novel, and one science fiction short story, where I know for a fact that I'm politically opposed to what they were saying. They were still good, and they still posited interesting, thought-provoking points. When people say "science fiction has always been political", they're not exactly wrong. It's just that 100% of the people I've seen who use that point are misusing it to mean that there's only room for their soapboxing.

>>32289292
One of the most annoying things about NuTrek is its insistence that its run of the mill, safe veneer of opinions over paint by numbers television is rooted in Trek's progressive history. Original Trek did shit that was downright rebellious to do at that time, and it often directly played with what it knew were predetermined convictions people held. There's an episode where the transporter splits Kirk into a Good and Evil half. But they're not Good and Evil, they're distinct parts of his personality and one half literally can't live without the other. They land on a planet where ravenous barbarians threaten the last civilized city, but the civilized people are authoritarian communists and the barbarians are literal Americans yearning for freedom (granted, it wasn't a good episode). There's a planet of Nazis doing terrible things, but fascism was only used as a tool by a well-meaning individual and it only went to shit when a selfish person took over.

And it did it back in a time when giving Spock pointy ears had people worried he might appear too Satanic.

Anonymous Sun 23 Aug 2020 00:27:41 No.32307833 Report

>>32307419
I can't wait for the running gag of Jazz being physically tossed out of the house by Uncle Phill to become a metaphor for internalized racism.

Anyway, I think the problem lies in an increasing number of people in these industries holding to what are essentially totalitarian views. The phrase "everything is political" gets thrown around a lot whenever people also say "X was always political". It boils down to an incapability to distinguish between something that is overtly espousing a political message (i.e. propaganda), and something that is influenced by the politics of the era. The latter covers every piece of fiction by definition. The Epic of Gilgamesh was probably a king trying to make himself look like a badass dude, but it doesn't put any particular ideology on a pedestal.

This idea that everything is a direct political action, and thus deserves to be affected by political policy, is something that only exists in totalitarian ideology. And totalitarian art tends to be simplistic because of this, because any sort of criticism, or even deviance, is seen as active hostility.
Anonymous

It's like how fucking badly Paul Verhoeven missed the mark on adapting Starship Troopers. Verhoeven basically pulled a 'too long, didn't read' on the book (true story, he didn't even read past chapter two) and then basically went with the popular misconceptions about Troopers being Heinlein's fascist manifesto. The stupid b-movie action flick that came out of this is good but I can't help but loathe Paul for actively disregarding what the book had to offer. Starship Troopers basically popularized the concept of power armor.

speaking of >>32309367
Brief setup of the story is a brotherhood Paladin goes up on an expedition of airships into the midwest, and it gets fucking wrecked. Now on his own and with no hope of the home chapter of the BoS sending rescue, he just says fuck it and strikes out on his own. Yes this is vaguely based on Fallout Tactics, at least to start with. Later when he's full Samurai Jack season 5 he ends up capturing a raider anthro, likely a badger or other roughcut species. They hate eachother at first as the Pally generally uses her as a tool to further his survival and gives her very little wiggle room. Circumstances force them together to a point that it starts forcing a change in their dynamic later on.

It's in the rough conceptual stages, nothing solid about later events on my mind yet, but my intent is to make it feel as lonely and desolate as early Fallout if I ever get around to it.

The last battle of the movie was the Federation Navy getting whacked while in orbit, which was not as graphic as the ground battles, which I feel leads the viewer to think of it as lesser. Once we're on the ground, we follow Rico and his squad on a rescue op for Carmen and Zane or Zack or whatever his name is. He gets his brains sucked out through the bug silly straw, Carmen is about to be next, but then Rico and his gang show up as shining paragons of military might and human courage, never leaving a man behind even in the most dire of circumstances and willing to sacrifice themsleves to do it.

Carmen is rescued, Sugar is injured and volunteers to stay behind with the nuke to seal the tunnel while "Klendathu Drop" plays, whose horns evoke images of otherworldy valor befitting of a heroes last stand and ultimate sacrifice, further glorifying mankind in contrast to the sea of mindless bugs.

Big eyes do not always mean expressive; the eyes were black and without pupils, as empty as we're supposed to believe the bugs are. The eyes nor "face" do not change shape to convey any sort of emotion whatsoever, which is why it took Carl the human psychic to figure out it was feeling any emotions whatsoever. The moment he announces "It's afraid!" is not a moment for reflection -- it's a moment of triumph, explicitly illustrated by the crowd of soliders erupting into cheers and celebratory gunfire.

The very very very last scenes of the movie are told in the "Would you like to know more?"-style propaganda reels that are sprinkled throughout the rest of the film, showing how mankind has new weapons, new soldiers, new leaders, and new resolve. Even the brain Bug, which you say we are supposed to feel for, is trated as a joke as it is seemingly dissected alive with a comedic "CENSORED" bar plastered over the scene as the scientist plunges the surgical tool into the bug's face.
